intro: Azalea heliolepis, commonly known as the golden azalea, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia, particularly found in regions of Malaysia and Indonesia. It belongs to the Rhododendron genus within the Ericaceae family, which includes many other azalea and rhododendron species. The plant is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and clusters of showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that bloom in shades of yellow and orange. Its flowers are typically 2–4 cm in diameter and are borne on short, erect pedicels. Azalea heliolepis thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and prefers partial to full sunlight, making it a popular choice for ornamental gardening in tropical and subtropical climates.
